body: @tcNickolas  regarding failed appveyor build.. I had a look.....One Transport server related test failed that has nothing to do with this.

@markusweimer I used majority voting to determine values - 26 out of 30 projects use empty company and trademark and just year in the copyright. I'm happy to use whatever we agree on. So you suggest:
- AssemblyCompany("The Apache Software Foundation.")
- AssemblyTrademark("The Apache Software Foundation")
- AssemblyCopyright("Copyright Â© 2016 The Apache Software Foundation")

Right?

Actually splitting AssemblyInfo.cs into common part and varying part doesn't look complicated: https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/jjameson/2009/04/03/shared-assembly-info-in-visual-studio-projects/

Since I'll have to edit all files with new values of the fields anyways (as opposed to 4 files when I used majority values), let me try and see if I can make it work. If I can, I'll update the JIRA accordingly.
For metrics2 in hadoop, is there any Neget we can just use or we have to port the source code over? Is there any evaluation for why we choose this one?

Fairly simple change, but my c++ skills are outdated. 
please review and comment

@markusweimer @tcNickolas @jwang98052  This is the next PR in the series. Please review.

Do we already have someone who needs to use VS2017 for daily development? The problem with keeping REEF build-able with different versions of VS is that we need to check that it still builds periodically. Otherwise we might introduce changes which break the build in VS2017 but work in previous versions (like we almost did for VS2013 before we had a dedicated AppVeyor job for that).

AppVeyor doesn't have a worker image for VS2017 yet, so it won't help us with this. And I don't think any of our clusters are going to switch to VS2017 (some of them still don't work with VS2015).

I don't object to this change, but I don't think we can say that REEF builds in VS2017 unless we verify this on a regular basis.

> I don't object to this change, but I don't think we can say that REEF builds in VS2017 unless we verify this on a regular basis.

Agreed. The intent here is to allow people to use and try VS 2017 without having to convert projects each and every time. I tested these changes with the current RC as well as VS 2015. As AppVeyor came back with a clean VS 2013 build, can we assume the changes to be benign?

Yes, as long as it doesn't break VS 2015 and VS 2013 builds it should be fine. Let me verify these two on my machine, and then I can merge.

Could you also update https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/REEF/Windows+PowerShell+Setup with instructions for VS 2017?

> Could you also update https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/REEF/Windows+PowerShell+Setup with instructions for VS 2017?

I tried. But the command line tools for VS 2017 are setup differently. I haven't found the `.bat` file that sets the command line up yet. This needs more investigation.
I will test and merge
@jwang98052 @tcNickolas @markusweimer gentle ping.
I'll test and merge.

The updated version should have addressed the following comments:

- `AssemblyInfo` is modelled after the similar file from `Org.Apache.REEF.IO`
- `.csproj` file should contain the link to SharedAssembly
- `StyleCop` checks should now pass
- there is the new `package.config` file for Stylecop MSBuild package
- `Org.Apache.REEF.sln` should contain only the necessary changes

Continuing on this:

> We should at least differentiate between read- and write- only streams just as the Java checkpoint service does.

The closest alternative I've found after reading System.IO docs is [BinaryWriter](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.io.binarywriter(v=vs.110).aspx) So we can provide a `BinaryWriter` instance to a client code for writing to a checkpoint. That would be a leaky abstraction, though, because that instance would also expose `Dispose` and `Close` methods which in principle should be called only by the checkpoint service.

So I suggest I implement an interface named like `CheckpointWriter` which exposes only a `Write(Byte[])`; and an example checkpoint service would internally implement this with sth like `BinaryWriter`.

@tcNickolas, @markusweimer Do you think it is a good idea ?
@jwang98052 @tcNickolas @markusweimer Gentle ping again for this PR :)
LGTM. Should test it on CISL cluster with 500 nodes for IMRUExample with FT option.

I've tested it (succeeded on 2nd try), but on CISL cluster evaluator failures in WaitingForEvaluator state are very rare, it's hard to hit this condition. I'm thinking we should merge it (unless there are some gaping holes in the logic), and then every time we run an IMRU job on other clusters we'll be testing this code path as well.

Is there any way to test this code path, other than wait for it to occur in environment tests? I'm not sure we can simulate evaluator unable to talk to driver in our tests...

Maybe we have to prioritize the work on cluster diagnostic jobs. I imagine such jobs would reproduce such issues more frequently than real IMRU jobs (being more lightweight and spending less time on doing real work)
Sounds good. I will test and merge.
@tcNickolas @motus @markusweimer I have addressed the review comments.
@markusweimer @jwang98052 @tcNickolas I have fixed all the review comments. Please take a look.

This is not related to the cluster size but data loading time or task initialization time, that is also related to machine speed and network speed. Little bit tricky to decide it on the fly. 
The current default setting is far too short. We didn't change it before because we didn't have cancellation token for this. Now with cancellation token set in WaitingForRegistration, it will not cause any side effect to make default a reasonable number for real scenarios.

Git doesn't show the diff in `.sln` file, so let me post it here (I used diff tool provided by Intellij via Git -> Show History to check that the change is exactly what I want). 

The problem was from line in project configuration platforms
`{F1A3495C-2CBD-4F3B-AEDC-9C1A43D9F238}.Release|x64.ActiveCfg = Debug|x64`
which set platform for this project to Debug when it was building in Release. You can check that for all other projects this line is `*.Release|x64.ActiveCfg = Release|x64`. Applying the same change here fixes the problem.

addressed comments and synced to the latest master.
ready for another review.

@tcNickolas I have addressed your comments.

A minor ask for future pull requests: please use commit message format as described in https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/REEF/Contributing. This makes merging the pull request much easier :-) If you put this information in pull request description, it doesn't propagate back to commit message, and has to be filled by hand
@markusweimer Do you still have concerns about this change? If not, I can test and merge.
LGTM. Will test and merge.

The change looks good in terms of project files creation. (Except there's a conflict in `.sln` file after #1196 is merged, you'll have to do one more iteration to resolve it)

One thing we need to consider is whether this package will need a separate nuget. If it will, you need to add `O.A.R.IO.Checkpoint.nuspec` file. I'm not sure how we decide whether each package should be a nuget or not. @jwang98052 Could you help with this question?

I'll let @markusweimer sign off on the meaningful part of the change :-)

LGTM, will fix one small typo in comments and merge. 

Then we'll have to watch for a repro of this type of failure during cluster testing to make sure it gets processed correctly, Yarn reports evaluator failure etc.

I'll merge this change for now for our cluster testing.

But what happens if we increase our data size further, so that data loading time grows to be more than 25 minutes? Will we need to modify our code again? If this parameter is sensitive to what we're doing in the task, it might make sense to make it configurable from the task, not hardcoded.
Is there a way to detect patterns of incorrect use of other parameters in the rest of our code?

Usually we only bind named parameter if user set a value. For IMRU, we get config data from IMRUJobDefinition, which contains its own default values. If the user doesn't set those values, its default will override the default in the named parameters. This is a typical case I have seen.  In fact, in IMRUJobDefinitionBuilder, some other variables that have default values also have similar issue and should be revisited.
@tcNickolas I have addressed your comments.

>> I suggest I implement an interface named like CheckpointWriter

> let @markusweimer sign off on the meaningful part of the change

I've already implemented a simplified checkpointing service that checkpoints to a local disk. 
Once I test it with an example REEF app, I'll push the changes to make interface discussion more focused.

Another option is to totally respect the default values defined in IMRUBuilderDefinationBuilder. It will override the default values of the named parameters. But it is by its choice. @tcNickolas what do you think?

I think that generally a more specific default value (value from some specific workflow) should override a more generic one (the value for parameter). If we're always using either generic default value or user-specified one, why do we need a more specific default value at all?

Usually we want to set default on named parameter so that user setting becomes optional. 

User can specify their specific default values that override generic default, it is fine. 

The issue is the "user" here is IMRU which is also part of REEF. When default are set at multiple places, that is confusion.

Per offline discussion, we should either not have a second (more specific) default value (and rely solely on the generic one) or have two default values and respect more specific one if it is set (the way we do for all other parameters in this code). Since we need second default value for configuration serialization purposes, let's stick with second option, respecting second default value properly. 

We can always use the same value for both defaults (and probably leave a comment for the more specific one saying that its default value should equal the generic default value, so that we're not tempted to modify them out of sync).
LGTM. Will test and merge.
@tcNickolas I have made a clean change and rebased.

I'll add a comment to state that new default value is taken from default for named parameter `MaxRetryNumberInRecovery`, test and merge.

We should also note that after this change default IMRU behavior is retry in case of a failure (prior to it retries were disabled by default).
Can we safely assume that master task completion = job success? Is there any way client code can postpone some actions until after task completion (e.g. for dispose)?
OK let's close it for now. Thanks for reviewing, though - I will incorporate the changes into another more comprehensive PR later.

I don't like the concept of closing pull request with 20+ comments and incorporating it into another one. It will be a pain for the reviewer to recover this pull request and check that the comments have actually been addressed. Is it possible to create a sub-task of REEF-1681 which focuses on introducing new parameter, and continue this PR to close it?
I completed a pass with some minor comments.

> Can we safely assume that master task completion = job success? Is there any way client code can postpone some actions until after task completion (e.g. for dispose)?

Based on the current IMRU Task code, master task returned from Call() method properly means the iteration has been completed and the result has been written successfully. But I would prefer not to use this one to enforce the termination of other tasks unless exceptional case happens such as evaluator failed ortask failed or task not returned after it.

What I meant is that PR does not change that much, but blocks more important functionality that I am working on right now. I would much prefer to not sweat over details of this PR now, but if you insist, I will reopen it and reduce the change to the minimum. (a new commit will follow shortly)
@markusweimer @tcNickolas Here goes the new version!
I have updated the code to shut down the job as soon as the master task is completed.

> Once I test it with an example REEF app, I'll push the changes to make interface discussion more focused.

@zerg-junior Is this PR ready for a review or shall I wait for that?

> Is this PR ready for a review or shall I wait for that?

@markusweimer  Wait for now, I still have to test the current implementation.

We should also look into properly modifying our fault-tolerance tests (there are some failures in AppVeyor with this change). Now that we don't know exactly how many completed tasks there will be, I think we should base our checks on the number of retries the system does (so a more high-level check than we previously had, a certain overall behavior with fewer specific checks).

This version of the change looks much smaller than the previous one :-) Did you decide to drop `TangUtils` and extra logging you had previously?

Other than that, LGTM. I can merge

@tcNickolas yes, I agree with @markusweimer that `TangUtils` is a hack in any form. Let's keep that functionality hidden so there is no temptation to reuse it elsewhere. Also, there was not much extra logging anyway, and it is likely I will do more logging in other modules in the subsequent PRs.

I've merged this

@tcNickolas I have addressed your review comments.

I think more tests should be updated... For example, `TestIMRUBroadcastReduceWithFTOnLocalRuntime` - if master task is not the last to complete, condition on line 54 doesn't hold, has to be inequality (https://ci.appveyor.com/project/ApacheSoftwareFoundation/reef/build/1215-master/job/n2tcmsg4q8kw459m/tests).

There is also an interesting failure of `TestFailMapperTasksOnDispose` (https://ci.appveyor.com/project/ApacheSoftwareFoundation/reef/build/1215-master/job/ympqhj60g0h3ukk2/tests) - there is an unexpected failed evaluator. I haven't seen this test fail before, so it might be caused by this change, although I don't see how
